Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Situation2: They are listed as the sole speaker for this week's congregational sermon, and the community has publicized their topic.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, headset pressing into my ears, as the clock inched toward noon. My telemarketing shift was relentless—calls queued up, and the compliance system tracked every second. If I left my desk even a minute outside my scheduled break, the system would flag me, and I’d risk a warning or worse. But today wasn’t just any Friday. I was the only imam scheduled for the Khutbah, and the community had already shared the topic I’d prepared. People would be gathering soon, expecting guidance and inspiration. My heart pounded as I weighed the demands: the company’s rigid rules versus my responsibility to the congregation. I imagined the disappointment if I didn’t show up, the trust I’d break. Yet, the fear of losing my job gnawed at me—rent was due, and my family depended on this income. The minutes ticked by, each one tightening the knot in my stomach as I wrestled with what to do.
